climbs.name: Mask Off
climbs.fa: Ethan Berkeland, Jonathan Koenig, and Tristan O'Donoghue May 2021

content.description: It's not everyday you're given the opportunity for a double knee bar on such a moderate route. climb shares the start of 20 second scrub and veers right at the obvious flake feature. lieback and knee bar up the flake to juggy face climbing. Move left at the at the top to shared upper anchor with 20 Second Scrub. Still a bit flaky in sections but nonetheless climbs very well.
content.protection: .75 or #1 cam to protect section below the flake. 6 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: 1st bolted line from the left side of the face between 20 Second Scrub and Corona Crack.

climbs.name: Journey through the Wiggly do's and the Wobbly don'ts

content.description: There's 3 reasons for the name of this route. The hike in from Birch Lake follows a straight line through the muskeg. I found many of the more marshy sections to be quite difficult to walk through. Some of the tussocks in the marsh I was using to cross will hold your weight (wiggly do's); some just throw you into the boggy mosquito infested water (wobbly don'ts).The better method of approaching this cliff, IMO, is via the Tanana river. The wiggly do's are the fun little rapids. The wobbly don'ts can launch your canoe to the less preferred side; unless you had hoped to get a swim in after your climbing session, this is not a suggested method of travel. When we first TR-ed, half of the holds were wobbly don'ts. These have cleaned up for the FA, however there are a few wiggly do's that will likely fall off with time. Also, the second bolt turned wobbly don't after I added locktite; best to clip the right of the two bolts.
content.protection: 5 bolts; two anchor chains. Options for #1-3 cam placement below the first bolt. I would bring a single #2 and runner for making the first clip.
content.location: Shorter, steeper wall that faces the river. Just right of a chossy chimney system. see pics

content.description: This line right of Corona Crack follows a splitter finger crack into cryptic face/compression climbing. It is a new Fairbanks test piece and a must do for the grade in Interior AK! Very unique climbing on a striking line.
content.protection: 6 bolts, a few finger size cams (.3-.75) and one #4 camalot
content.location: Right of Corona crack, two bolts lead to obvious finger crack

content.description: A short and steep crack. The climb begins with a short section of sporty climbing up to easy climbing on ledges. From the second ledge, launch off into the crux on overhanging jams to a difficult top out on flaring jams and face holds.
content.protection: Gear to 1, doubles recommended, tape recommended, two bolt anchor
content.location: Obvious splitter on climbers right side of the crag. The approach trail to the bottom of the crag passes this climb first.

climbs.name: Corona Crack
climbs.fa: Ethan Berkeland, Jonathan Koenig and Tristan Odonoghue May 2020

content.description:
This is a truly fantastic route for the interior and makes the hike to the bluffs worthwhile. 

 Start just to the right of 20 Second Scrub with 5.9 face climbing until you reach the top of the pedestal where the crack begins. The crux is Immediately after gaining the crack and is easier for taller people(allegedly). Once you reach the hand jam pull one more slightly reachy move to easier climbing (5.9) which ends at the anchor.
content.protection: Single rack to 4. Extra .75 is helpful to protect crux. #4 used at first large pod off the deck. 2 bolt anchor. A bolt was added at the start to eliminate the runout.
content.location: Crack just right of 20 Second Scrub in the middle of face.

climbs.name: 20 Second Scrub
climbs.fa: Ethan Berkeland, Jonathan Koenig and Tristan Odonoghue May 2020

content.description: Ascend up a lower angle ramp with loose rock to a more vertical face with a discontinuous crack system next to a chimney feature. Stay near chimney until no longer able to stem and mount the upper section(crux). Layback and smear up crack on great rock passing old anchor to higher up 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: Single rack to 3. Extra 2s and 3s would make the last 25 feet much easier to protect.
content.location: Left most crack when looking at bluff from below.

content.description: This is the first concentrated area of recent development at the bluffs and has several prominent cracks of different sizes(fingers,hands, OW) that split the rock. Use the bolted boulder on top of the formation to rappel over ledge and set up TRs. All possible lines at the area now have bolted anchors. It is highly encouraged to do any cleaning/development of climbs with a degree of caution and as potential for having loose rock. South facing sun all day and breeze coming off the river make this crag a true gem.
